headline: Interviews and Nascent Experience -- Dallas Office
pros:
So, I'm going to share my experience with the interview process and my initial experience in the Dallas office. First, I want you to keep in mind this is an investment firm and all the connotations that come with that; second, I'd like you to note my personality -- I'm high-strung and type A; if I'm not tired, busy, or stressed, then I'm not happy; and last, I chose this field because I wanted something intellectually stimulating, something to keep me busy, and something that will compensate me for my obsessive work habits. So, when reading what I've put down as pros, remember this context. In other words, my pros may not be ones for you. 

Interview experience: quick, more informal (but not completely), and well-guided. The person I worked with in HR/Recruiting was Christen Zellinger. And honestly, she was pretty fantastic. She set up interviews, made sure I was posted throughout the entire experience, and kept any personal-life quirks in mind while interviewing (I was going to be without service for a weekend). She was very pleasant and conversational. I think we were able to connect as much as a candidate and an HR recruiter can, and her personality made this possible. 

Relocating: I ended up relocating to the Dallas office. This experience was fast-paced. However, I felt supported (as much as a company can support you) while doing this: I was given a reasonable amount of money to move; I was given resources, information, and contacts; I was also given emails from my team on which neighborhoods to explore, etc. That’s not to say moving wasn’t stressful because, quite frankly, I think stress innate to the process, but I knew I had resources if I needed them. 

The Office: We are currently in Las Colinas for the office, but a new one is being built in the middle of Uptown/Knox-Henderson (really "cool," trendy areas. I'm actually really excited about the new location.) Now, Las Colinas is fine. It's a typical office/workplace community -- there's offices, a few restaurants, and then most people leave to go back to their living communities. Is it the best place? No. But is this completely manageable for ~6 months while they finish the new building? Absolutely. (The plus here is the new office/future workspace.)

The Office (cont.): Now, concerning the workplace culture, this is where I think people are a little shocked, but I'm not sure why. During my interview process, my team repeatedly asked me if I was okay with the following: a busy schedule, quickly learning a lot of information, being available for work calls/deals/etc., and occasionally having to work weekends. I've done a lot of research; I've worked at (literally) the top investment bank; I knew what to expect. And so, when I got to the office and saw people working/staying late, I wasn't shocked. This is literally what I was told to expect and have already experienced, and then I got it -- but this is the kind of career I wanted and what fits my personality. So, in my book, the company was completely transparent and then delivered, most companies are not like this. Their candor is an incredible plus to me.
cons:
Read until the end or else this will just feel like a lot of what I've already said (see pros): This is a very niche environment in terms of the entire career spectrum. Meaning, you should not come here expecting a Silicon Valley and/or startup culture. If you want a typical 9-5 with predictable hours and moderate pay, this isn’t the place. This is going to be a demanding position (most likely, I can't speak for all teams/career paths) but you'll be well compensated. 

Now, because of this specialized culture, I do think they're lacking in diversity. That is, my office is pretty white, cis, heterosexual male (seeming, at least). Now, my team, which consists of ~7 people, is pretty good for the finance industry: i.e. a person of color is the head management, other team members of color, we have females, and a member of the queer community (and yes, they're all separate people). But the (Dallas) office, overall, is very white, very male, etc. and females/people of color tend to be in administrative roles. However, I think there is a push to remedy this; and I think it's worth mentioning that there are other socio-economic barriers impacting this sample that, quite frankly, I don't think a single firm can solve for an industry. 

So, if you're looking for an environment that is already wildly diverse, you're not going to find it here. However, if you're an individual that is comfortable with being part of a push for more diversity (without being tokenized), then I think this a safe bet. Because, honestly speaking, I don’t think anyone really cares as long as you’re good at your job -- at least, that’s my impression.

Was able to leave when all work was done at the end of the day, nobody lays the guilt trip on you when you are done with your work for the day.
cons: Long hours, as with every job sometimes.  Not personally, but i know that some teams work from 9am-10pm every night including most weekends.  High turnover in in these departments.

headline: Excellent place to work!
pros: Great people, compensation and environment.  Executives work as hard as they expect everyone else too which is great to see.
cons: Be prepared to put your time in but if you do you will be well compensated.

headline: Stifling
pros: The benefits are great, and the pay isn't bad.
cons: You will never get promoted and your ideas will be ignored.  No one in a position to care about your career does anything to help further you along.  HR department is unproductive for employees.

headline: Extreme micromanagement
pros: Reputable well diversified hedge fund and the pay is pretty good.  Working hours are decent, exposure to various credit investments.
cons: Poor management and governance.  No autonomy or scope for career growth.  Extreme micromanagement and red tape.  No appreciation for one's work.  No morale boosting.

headline: Satisfied, but no career growth.
pros: Ability to wear many hats.
cons: Pigeon hold into one position.

headline: Fortress is a great place to grow
pros: Firm is increasing its AUM
cons:
Hierarchical, though people say it is not.  Hard to get promoted
Firm grew too fast too quickly
Lack of IT infrastructure

headline: Great money, but where did my soul go?
pros: MONEY, bonuses etc. Great access to the latest technology. Company spares no expense to do things efficiently.
cons: Long hours, cut-throat corporate environment, lack of civic responsibility. Not family-friendly.

headline: Like the people, but excessive turnover
pros: Reasonably flexible investment approach, people willing to get creative.  There are a number of very smart individuals, not all, but most.
cons: A little unstable, can make jerky reactions to markets and major strategic changes based on temporary market conditions.  I was satisfied with my pay package but have heard from a lot of people who weren't.

headline: Great experience
pros: Very involved and active work environment. A lot of deals pass by your table so you get to acquire an insight into different market cap, sector  etc . companies and different valuation and financing methods.
cons: Not very organized and 'one firm' culture is not implemented that well. Different parts of the company ( private equity, hedge fund etc...) are mostly treated as separate entities even when they could be leveraging each other.
